Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSE: Collaborative Research: Lagrangian Coherent Structures for Accurate Flow Structure Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The Lagrangian Coherent Structures (LCS) software elements developed by this project will provide a valuable tool set for fluid mechanics research to extract new discoveries from the vast and growing body of computational and experimental fluid mechanics data. The computation of LCS enables a systematic approach to accurately characterize transport phenomena in complex systems that pose insurmountable challenges to traditional Eulerian approaches. Prior, ah hoc implementations of LCS have already helped in important, real-world challenges including, tracking pollutants in the ocean, developing novel diagnoses and therapies for cardiovascular disease, and helping airplanes to avoid turbulence. We will produce an open LCS software system to provide a modular, extensible and flexible infrastructure to broaden the community of scientists and engineers that benefit from LCS, in problems ranging from fluid dynamics to general dynamical systems. Prof. Shadden will lead the LCS algorithm design and numerical analysis, and Prof. Hart will oversee the package's architectural design and the efficient parallel implementation of its elements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our NSF SI2-SSE collaborative research project titled Lagrangian Coherent Structures for Accurate Flow Structural Analysis (#1047764) was designed to produce a software library for computing and visualizing structures in time varying flow.

Our "final" year included further work of intellectual merit on new methods for both computing flow structures and visualizing the structures. Our main contribution to this library is the "fastvection" method for fast GPU advection of particles through an unsteady (timevarying flow) through an unstructured (tetrahedral) mesh. We achieved a new state of the art in performance of particle advection by using the GPU and its recent shared memory capabilities. In order to achieve this unprecedented performance, we set up a blocked shared memory layout, and carefully tuned the parameters for blocked memory management to ensure peak performance. The intellectural merit of this exercise is that it reveals further insight in General Purpose GPU (GPGPU) programming in the details of shared memory management for manycore parallel processing. The results of this intellectual exercise have been submitted for publication to IEEE Transactions for Visualization and Computer Graphics, but have been tied up with minor revisions needed to satisfy the reviewers concerns.

An additional intellectual merit is on the extraction of Lagrangian coherent structures from flow data. We have introduced the idea of using hierarchical watershed methods, developed originally for segmenting image data for computer vision and image processing, for extracting regions of similar flow topology. We have written this work up in a paper presented at TopoInVis 2015 and will appear in an upcoming Springer book on its proceedings.

The main broader impact of this work is an open source publicly available  software library for computing and visualizing flow. This library is the FlowVC library that has been developed and maintained by collaborating PI Shawn Shadden and his students in Mechanical Engineering at UC Berkeley. We have incorporated the fastvection GPU advection routines into FlowVC, and await publication of the fastvection paper to announce the availability of FlowVC to increase its adoption and utilization by the flow visualization communit.

An additional broader impact is the education of Mingcheng Chen, the main RA of this project, and both the fastvection work and the new technique for watershed LCS visualization will form the bulk of his Ph.D. dissertation. A further broader impact is the collaboration with Shawn Shadden, between CS and ME, and between UIUC and UC Berkeley. This collaboration is working so well that Mingcheng Chen will be completing the last year of his research in Shadden's lab at Berkeley working with his students.
